reviewText:
This is a long review so if you just want a brief summary of why I recommend Serious Sam 2 then skip to Results and read from there.

Serious Sam 2 is a fun game that offers more ridiculous combat, but drifts a little too far from the Serious Model to be called â€œGreatâ€. After the success of the original Croteam had a higher budget to put towards Serious Sam 2; sadly, Serious Sam 2 takes a path similar to the Martix 2 where an increased budget leads to a worse product. The game albeit fun has some additions which take away from the hilarity and well-crafted elements that made the series great.

Story:
Serious Sam finally meets the Sirians, the race that in the future Mental destroyed before his attack on humanity. The Sirians noticed Samâ€™s serious combat skills from the First and Second encounter so they portal him to their ship. It is there that they tell him of his prophecy, to defeat Mental and free the universe.  To do this Sam must venture to five planets and acquire the five pieces of the medallion. Only then will he be able to weaken mental and eliminate him once and for all. His quest will take him to five planets  in order to retrieve the pieces of the medallion from four tribes: the Simbas, Zixies, Chi Che, and Elvians. It is up to Sam to either save each of these groups from Mentals oppression and retrieve their medallion pieces.

Campaign:
Serious Sam 2 is divided into seven planets: Mâ€™digbo, Magnor, ChiFang, Kleer, Ellenier, Kronor, and Serius. The campaign consists of a whopping forty-two levels (including boss fight levels). Unlike the First and Second Encounter some of the levels are not nearly as long or engrossing.

Gameplay:
Similar to the previous titles of Serious series the difficulty curve is well managed, where you can make it ridiculously hard or meticulously difficult. Serious Sam 2 introduces new weapons, and battle concepts. You can now get 200 health/armor by picking up any health packs (unlike the original where you could only go over 100 if you found special health/armor packs). By allowing you to get 200 health/armor Serious Sam 2 really builds upon the originals gameplay by giving you more control in how you will fight, but this is short lived as the weapon choices and ammo limitations dampen the combat. You will rarely find ammo throughout the campaign, and when you do you will burn through it without being able to find more. I found myself using the Auto Shotgun and Double Shotgun almost the entire campaign as I never had enough ammo for the other weapons.

Upon venturing to new planets you lose all your items, meaning you have to start collecting weapons all over again. This would be fine, but I noticed in Mâ€™digbo I only acquired nine of the fourteen weapons. Every time you start a new level you revert back to 100 health and lose your armor. This means if you performed well on the previous level all is in vain because you losing all your work anyway. You also have lives in this game, so you may think you are reloading a past save but actually its putting you back at a checkpoint with one less life.

Hints:
>Save between each area, then if you die load your save (this way you donâ€™t lose lives).
>Save your ammunition in the first and second planets (after the first two planets, ammunition is plentiful).
>Forget about ending the level with full health/armor (you lose your health/armor between levels).
>Make sure you load your campaign from the save files (as you lose any lives you acquired earlier otherwise).
>Make sure when you die to reload from the save file (if you just click continue it will revert you back to the last checkpoint and you will not have the armor/ammo/health you had when you actually got to the checkpoint).
>If your level glitches, try saving and reloading the level right where you saved. (This can cause the enemies to spawn allowing you to get past enemy kill-count triggers related issues)
>On the second planet level â€œForsaken Compoundâ€ is known to glitch on Hard or Serious Difficulty. If the rocket launcher does not spawn after you get right across the bridge your level has glitched and you need to restart.

Results:
Serious Sam is an epic first person shooter series that pushes the limit and then takes it further. The action is amazing, the bosses are intense, and the enemies are plentiful. You wonâ€™t be solving any puzzles in this one, but instead you will be gunning down the masses. There are five planets; each planet has its own unique design and unit models. The campaign offers loads of different elements that make you want to push on, making each level more epic than the last. If you want a realistic game this is not for you, but if you donâ€™t mind going crazy having a good time Serious Sam 2 is the game for you. I would get this with the Serious complete back (only if you can grab it on sale). Honestly if you just want to try out a new game $9.99 is a little high for this game.

Pros:
+Interesting new enemies, some which play off the originals and some that are completely unique.
+Introduction of vehicles (makes some of the levels a little more serious).
+Secrets are more amusing
+Six separate planets to visit all with their quirks.
+Enemies have themes to match their locations.
+Levels offer much more variation in play-style and ambience.
+More bosses which require various tactics to defeat.
+Fun, explosive, and fast paced gameplay that keeps you wanting more.
+Netrisca can talk (you still have to read some things, but she will just tell you major clues).
+Ability to have multiple profiles, so if you are sharing a computer you can easily switch between other individuals campaigns.
+Blasting thousands of enemies to bits as you run around like a true action hero.
+Lots of nostalgia!!!!

Cons:
-Poor cinematic quality (itâ€™s as if the cinematics are actually lower quality than the gameplay).
-Introduction of allies (you never needed them before â€“ why now?)
-You lose your weapons upon starting up at a new planet (although this occurs also between campaign transitions in TSE the campaign for Serious Sam 2 connects each planet into a single campaign).
-You have lives (you never had lives before this)
-You always start each level with 100 health (regardless of whether you had more or less at the end).
-Some of the levels have bugs, which force you to restart the level.
-You lose Serious Bombs between levels.
-There is not one point in the campaign where you have every single weapon at one time. (Except for on the final level)
-Levels are nowhere near as large as TFE or TSE.
-Awful dialogue (attempts to be funny, but falls short atleast for me)
-Too childish (the game has cartoonish unit models that take away from the Serious in Serious Sam)

Serious Sam 2 is the third part of the main series of the Serious Sam games, but technically it is the 'newest' part in the continuity.

This is a great game.

Back in 2005 when the game originally came out, it made mayor strides in comparison to the first two games. Many dislike where it went, but I really enjoy the outcome of the game.
The graphics are cartoonish and very bright and really make a difference to the earlier titles and the chosen music and sound assets are pretty awesome. Just the the music of some levels is worth the money. And the cutscenes? Those are pretty yanky but also pretty hilarious, although they suffer a bit from pretty high compression artifacts.
The gameplay has not really changed fro the earlier titles. You come to an area, doors close, you slauther a bunch of enemies and just continue to the next section. It might sound boring, but the level design really hides those 'grindy' parts.
The arsenal is also pretty much the same as in 'The First Encounter' or 'The Second Encounter', just updated and added some cool twists (exploding birds, hand grenades).

So all in all, if you like the previous titles and like games of this genre you might like this one too.

reviewText:
Serious Sam 2 is a game with a proper budget and is worse for it. This might sound a little strange but part of the charm of the original Encounters were their simplicity. They were the most first person shooter you had ever seen in a first person shooter. Their success has now lead Croteam to develop Serious Sam 2 with some loftier goals in mind and unfortunately this only makes the game worse for wear.

The first new introduction you'll get is to the storyline which now takes a front seat in the game together with cut-scenes. Both are unfortunately very poorly made and do nothing to pull you further into the game. On the contrary the constant breaks in the action where you have to sit around and watch Sam try to be funny ruins the pace of the game and makes the dreaded boredom begin to set in.

Sam was always a funny character in the originals. In the same way that Duke was fun back in Duke 3D. The cute little adolescent one liners made you giggle a little in between stomping out alien scum. In Serious Sam 2 however these one liners have been ramped up and pushed into the cut scenes and the increased intensity of the, coupled with the fact that you are no longer playing the game when they happen, you are sitting around waiting for the cut scene to end, means that you will begin to get sick of them very quickly.

Serious Sam 2 does maintain some the good qualities too and make a few cool additions of it's own. The weapons are still fun and varied, sound great and feel great. The levels are still massive with hordes of enemies and an absolutely absurd amount of color thrown in there to offset the modern shooter's often too heavily reliance on brown and grey.

The enemies look great and are every bit as varied and insane as in the original, everything from headless bombers to giant American footballers and psycho clowns on unicycles.

All in all Serious Sam 2 isn't a bad game. Underneath it all it still got everything that made the First and Second Encounters so enjoyable. It's just picked up some bad habits which hurt the overall feel of the game.

reviewText:
Short version: 68% The most infantile entry of the Serious Sam franchise is full of design problemsâ€“ including the painfully dumb humourâ€“ but the second half of the game somewhat makes up for the horrible levels that plague the start.

Long version:The Serious Sam franchise is a series of first-person shooters, where the player takes the role of â€œSeriousâ€ Sam Stone, the lone survivor of the human race. Samâ€™s task is to somehow change the timeline by defeating a mysterious alien warlord called Mental and his vast army of minions. To accomplish this, he is armed with a gigantic arsenal, including every cheesy 80s action movie one-liner ever written.

Except for this game. Because Serious Sam 2 is about an idiot running around at the order of three midgets to gather the pieces of a cheap amulet from the clutches of witches, zombie lawyers, cigar-smoking dinosaurs, monocycling clowns, and other cartoonish enemies.
It is true that the series always had some infantile humour, but mostly in the form of secrets or the occasional random occurrences. Here, the dumbness is the main attraction, and it was so contagious that it swallowed the brains of the level designers too. The non-linear courtyards and arenas that characterise the other games are replaced with 10-15 minute long corridors. The only time the game opens up is when it showcases how well it stole vehicle riding segments from Halo 1-2.

There are only a few redeeming factors. Starting from the fourth world, the levels start to almost feel like an actual game, not just a bad engine tech demo. Also, even the bad stages have an astonishing amount of detail at almost every corner, so at least they are pretty to look at. Very pretty: CroTeam made a great job with Serious Engine 2. While originally it was a demanding beast, by todayâ€™s standards, it is old yet still looks stunning for its age. Well, apart from the physics engine, but thankfully the terrible physics are just for show (except for getting a few secrets).

reviewText:
Ultimately boring and stale experience.
First of all, SS2 aged really, really bad. It looks (especially on higher resolutions, where the game doesn't scale well) and plays much worse than original Encounters.
I can dig into changed tone and cartoon worlds, but not in a game that is about running in circles and killing hundreds and thousands of enemies. While the image of hell hordes of gore in Encounters and SS3 simply involves you into it, where hipster blood is there as an option for a second to enjoy, the SS game doesn't works if the whole game is filled with pastel colours straight from the Smurfs. And characters from Smurfs - killing over and over cartoon witches, goblins, natives having sex in bushes and finding a poop in a yard gets boring very quickly.
Sound assets surely don't help the game in that matter. The happy-go tracks that don't build any tension whatsoever make the boredom come even sooner. They're just so out of place and situation for most of the time.
Weaponry feels and sounds weak, with the only exception of double barrel shotgun. The rest of it gets boring really quickly and I almost never used any besides occasional rocket launcher and sniper rifle. I didn't get far into the game, but the slow pace of introducing new challanges and weapons made me not to care about what's further in the game. I found the cannon in the first episode/arc and never used it. Why to bother playing it when you can dig into Encounters or SS3? Now I know there is no reason at all of doing so.

Also, often crashes and sound problems are irritiating.

reviewText:
Serious Sam 2 doesn't take itself seriously on the surface, but as a hardcore fan of tough slaughterfest FPS bullet/melee hell gameplay that this franchise is known for, I give this game a serious thumbs up.

I am by no means an inexperienced player so trust me, if I say a game is hard it's probably tougher than what you'd expect and SS2 is surprisingly difficult which is a refreshing revamp of the series that delivers exactly what real fans wanted. Normal in SS2 feels more like hard in SS1 a lot of the time and the tricks up the dev's sleeves perform nicely and will have you strategizing more than shooting on various occasions.

The weapons have a pleasant, balanced feel to them that encourages you to get creative and never have an ultimate go-to. Yes some weapons are of course better for certain situations than others, but seldom will you feel like you'd be screwed if you didn't have ammo for a specific weapon. The Devs are good about giving you the ammo you need, and you see ammo packs, large health and powerups much more often in this installation of the series making way for big fights equally more often.

Enemies are what you'd expect, but there's some awesome additions especially ranged enemies. In the first game, most of the ranged attacks were projectiles but in SS2 there's more rockets and more bullets to force you to kill fast, fast fast and prioritize targets effectively if you want to stay alive for long. Also, there's more strategy involved in taking down enemies this time around. One of the first enemies has a shield that it'll drop when you shoot it, but I'm pretty sure making contact while before it drops the shield does more damage. I'm not positive about that though. Either way, more strategy difficulty and satisfaction.

The environments are pretty epic and vary just enough to keep you happy without getting overly obnoxious. There's moments where you say Damn

reviewText:
I was dared to play this game to completion, and I regret it immensely. While I successfully completed the game, I feel as though a part of me is now missing.

This game is soul crushingly boring and tedious, and while that is part of the Serious Sam style of game play, it entirely misses the point of what made the first two games fun.

This game makes you feel small, slow, and generally not very powerful. The enemies soak up huge amounts of damage even on lower difficulty levels and while the previous game had specific weapons to use against specific enemies, this one has several enemies that seem to have no weaknesses, and they enjoy throwing them at you in huge quantities(Footballers)

While there are sometimes big open areas and arenas in this game, you are often specifically confined to much smaller arenas than the previous game, and the designers just toss enemies one by one at you for 5-10 minutes. The developers even seem to realize that this is annoying because there are several voice callouts that Sam makes that emphasis that they are just tossing fodder at you in a padded fashion.

The game is split up into 7 distinct sections, the worst of them being the TV challenge series section and the ice world levels, where they introduce a resource mechanic where Sam will freeze to death, yes, Serious Sam will freeze to death, the man who can walk in lava. There are long auto scroller sections often with downtime or enemies on all sides, while confining you to extremely small areas and giving you very little in the way of dodging room. At one point there is a sewer level and the developers thought they were clever by saying all games had sewer levels and making it a maze, but it only calls out how much everyone hates these levels and it drags on far too long to be humorous.

While the developers added many new enemies to this game, they all behave as re-skins of existing enemies and don't add to the variety in play styles. Many of the enemies that people lamented from the previous games are back and more annoying than ever, almost as though they thought it would be a good idea to harass players of the existing games for having the audacity to question their design decisions. The flying enemies move around waaaay too much and too fast, and while you can usually lead them around, they tend to cluster directly above you where you can't easily aim, or stay way off in the distance where very few of the weapons they give you are effective.

They added turrets and vehicles to the game this time around, and it was a huge mistake. While the turrets are typically optional to use, the quantity and rate at which they throw enemies at you implies that they expect you to use them. Anchoring the player down is in stark contrast to the run around at the speed of light I loved in the previous game. The vehicles are typically overpowered and you just hold down mouse one and abuse the infinite ammo until it forces you to get back out of the vehicle. On rare occasions you get out to pull out the minigun and shoot down the flying enemies that you can't hit with the vehicle weapons.

The audio comes off as polished, but wears thin quickly. With as much as you hear the weapons sounds and musical tracks that don't fit with what you're doing, you grow tired of them, and I eventually turned off the music and turned down the sound effects to listen to something that wasn't going to put me into a coma.

The game while generally technically competent and feels polished, has a glaring technical flaw. For a game where almost every enemy runs straight at the player, the pathfinding in this game is horrendously broken if there are any obstacles. The enemies often spread out and run in the opposite direction of you, don't notice you at all, or get stuck behind objects that really should have been accounted for in the levels. This leads to parts of the game where you hunt around for several minutes trying to find the last few enemies that have become stuck in the level before the game lets you continue on. (You must kill all enemies to continue through the level.)

The pacing of the game is rather poor, and it takes away your weapons at the start of each of the 7 distinct sections and makes you run around collecting them, creating a saw wave difficulty curve, and ends up simply annoying more than interesting. They knew they didn't have enough content to make the game the 8.5 hours that it enforces on you, and it shows everywhere, leading to long drawn out sections that are neither harder, nor easier than the previous, just more of the same. If you finished the first three sections of the game, you've seen the rest. It's just another set piece behind the same tedious actions.

The boss design is typical Serious Sam, where you don't shoot the boss yourself, but play some gimmick that hurts the boss. Most bosses are invincible to player weapons(not technically but you could shoot them for an hours, run out of ammo and still not kill them), and they don't feel particularly rewarding to defeat. The first boss is possibly the most insulting boss I've ever seen in a game. If you take no action, the boss dies within 1-2 minutes, with no involvement. It's a protect the AI while the AI kills the boss" battle

Cons:

This game was a bit of a surprise, but I'll get to that in a moment.

Let's clarify something - I've bought this game for about 0,79E about a week ago and never played it before.

I finished this vanilla game on normal difficulty in under 20 hours, I was searching for all secrets. It is a long game with many different levels and environments.

Pros:
- nice graphics
- weapons look better than in First & Second encounters - especially plasma rifle is really pretty and useful and the cannon looks badass
- some new enemies do look good - zombie lawyers, flying kleers, kung fu masters
- this game is long, although levels take about 10-15 minutes to finish, sometimes even less
- many varied levels
- the game is challenging at some stages

Cons:
- this game is long - sometimes there are tedious things to do before advancing to the next level like killing every single enemy
- this is not like previous Serious Sam, this is a totally different game!
- where are old enemies like Gnaars, beheaded troopers, biomechanoids (sorry, T-rex mech smoking pipe is just weird). Instead we have stupidly looking clowns that are basically faster kamikaze trooper, some space orks with guns(?), witches flying on brooms (?) and some white apes shooting energy balls (duh)
- some weapons are really weak in comparison to their function - like rocket launcher has really small damage, dual uzis are good only for weak enemies, grenade launcher is made available only later in the game, dual barrel shotgun is weak
- the plot is stupid and pointless
- there are not as many secrets as in First & Second encounters
- there are no messages and encyclopaedia as in previous games where you could read funny stuff about enemies, items, levels and so on

So, vanilla Serious Sam 2 is a really disappointing game to me. I've expected something like Serious Sam Third Encounter but instead got something like Serious Sam the Spin-off. I would certainly not recommend this game...

Untill I've played this Insamnity mod that is already built into the steam game. While playing the first level I saw beheaded troopers. Wow. Later I saw Gnaars. A big plus. The author of the mod probably deleted all of the clowns, because I don't remember seeing one. The game was running better and faster after running the Insamnity mod. There are even more enemies and this is finally providing a challenge worthy of Serious Sam name.

Really, if not for the mod I would not recommend this game. This one mod saves the whole game and now it finally feels like home. Like a Serious Sam game should feel.

Serious Sam wasn't ever serious, but this one is absolutely stuffed to the gills with zany. There's a lot of awkward, miss-the-mark humour in it. The old bestiary have been remade as silly cartoons, although bizzarely some of the new additions are unimaginative humanoids, and some of them commit the sin of having hitscan weapons, making them priority targets despite being lowly minions.

You still mow things down with a minigun, then do it some more, then finally maybe it'll let your index finger uncurl for some dancing-with-kleer and a double shotgun. Except both at the same time. While popping off some rockets at a giant spider in the distance, and sniping a helicopter sweeping across the fray. The offhand grenades are an excellent addition for adding a little extra firepower and rewarding you for herding enemies into clumps.

You still can't rocket-jump without taking your legs off below the knee, but you can still run at 30MPH on your last hitpoint, desperately dancing and weaving through laser blasts toward a health pickup. Cover is something you blow up to deny it to the enemy. It's still Serious Sam, and it's not got the vast expanses of the first, but it's still big. And twice as long as you might think at first. A lot of stuff happens, and it's not lacking in variety of scenery and experience. Even the turret and vehicle sections are welcome shake-ups to what otherwise might be twenty hours of the minigun spinning.

And it's nice to have Sam moving *towards* MENTAL for once, not sideways, or backwards into prequels. For all its screwed-up tone, and some lousy and unfun early-level design (what were they THINKING with the single shotgun?), by the finale it's one adrenaline build-up after another.

reviewText:
Serious Sam 2
Serious Sam 2,a campaign game and a FPS shooter is the sequel to Serious Sam: The Second Encounter. The main objective of this game is to bring down Mental and his vile armies. For that, the player has to battle through thick jungles, murky swamps, frozen tundra, and futuristic cities.  The player is able to obtain better gear and epic vehicles as time progresses.  Tired of campaign? No worries, Serious Sam 2 offers co-op and deathmatch chaos. Besides that, its soothing soundtrack and scenic levels motives the player to carry on their endeavour.

Pros
+ Easy to control and navigate the character.
+ Cartoony graphics.
+ Beautiful maps and environment.
+ Unique maps and levels, battle accross more than 40 levels!
+ Contains different species" of enemies including bosses.
+ An array of weapons
date:
vehicles and turrets that keeps you wanting for more.

Cons
- Players start each level with 100 health regardless of whether the player had more or less at the end.
- Have a life system which some might find annoying.
- Players loose Serious Bombs between levels.

Final Rating: 9/10"

Serious Sam 2 is my favorite game in the franchise because it takes a huge step away in terms of art style and story telling from the First and Second Encounter. Serious Sam 2 is a whole lot more colorful and silly, and that's why I love it. The gun design is really wacky and over-the-top, with a ten barrell shotgun, a huge rocket launcher that takes up half the screen, a parrot that carries a bomb and kamikazies where ever you throw it and more. The world is very beautiful too, taking place on some alien planet full of color, huge trees, and lots of cool and different villages for you to explore. The monster design is awesome too. The gameplay is the same if you've ever played a Serious Sam game, and that's alright. There are also vehicles and turrets that you can use which are pretty cool as well.

If you're in the market for a arcade shooter where you can mow down endless waves of baddies, I think this is the best game to get. Awesome graphics, beautiful enviroments, and overall very fun gameplay.

reviewText:
Serious Sam 2 strays far, really far from its predecessor.

Pros: Setting, Humor, Controls
Cons: Story, Repetitiveness

Serious Sam continues his adventures on several different worlds in the universe, all of which feel different and well-developed.  Humor abounds, though not all of it funny, like Sam's bouts of flatulence.  Controls are simple, consisting mostly of strafing and holding the fire button.

Serious Sam 2 sets the stage for the final confrontation with the main villain, Mental, but the story and ending are very, very disappointing.  One of Serious Sam's namesakes, endless waves of enemies, feel monotonous rather than epic.  Enemies seem more like reskins of each other rather than new and interesting creations.

Serious Sam's serious fans will likely be disappointed, but new players may enjoy the crass humor and cartoony machinations.

6/10

This game is adorable: light-hearted, briskly paced, sarcastic, and while not at all thougtful in itself, inspiring a little thought in the player. The gameplay and your opponents are a kitchen sink of first-person shooters, with characters from everything from /Doom/ to /Halo/ (just the Covenant), as well as the occasional Conan the Barbarian reference; the settings of the game are various cliche game settings, from the /Far Cry/ planet to the /Doom/ planet to the /Big Trouble in Little China/ and /World of Warcraft/ planets. The effect is not to be missed; there's something unique, beautiful, even haunting about driving a light tank and fighting helicopters in front of the gates of a fairy-tale castle.

Why do these planets retain their distinctive character, despite Mental's occupation? _How_ do they do so, given that Mental's homeworld is gleaming and hyper-modern, and surely produces the sort of abundant, cheap consumer goods that have caused the Middle East and East Asia to lose their distinctive visual character? Perhaps Mental doesn't permit free trade between his own planet and his colonies, but this seems unlikely; more likely, perhaps his homeworld is a command economy (Mental is an AI, after all), and just doesn't produce enough of a surplus of anything -- or have enough interest in peaceful trade -- to provide blue jeans and televisions cheap enough for the people of the Far Cry world to afford...

Mental's manpower also doesn't appear to be as good as it could be; he's dependent on local levies to keep order, and his regular troops -- Warhammer-style orcs supported by heavy military hardware -- seldom show up in large numbers outside of small numbers of major bases and garrisons. This despite the orcs having access to antibiotics and vaccination, Green Revolution agriculture, computerized manufacturing, and all sorts of other things that should be keeping their numbers up relative to their enemies... but command economies aren't really known for high population growth.

It's an interesting puzzle; it certainly produces a memorably combined visual character; and it does seem to have an answer in the end. I doubt that the writers knew that Serious Sam is fighting the AI Soviet Union, but the internal evidence does point that way...

I wonder what inspired this company to write this game. They certainly make some amusing points about how there's a shared culture of video games that shouldn't exist, looking at the matter a priori -- there's no reason why everyone should use the same types of characters and settings. But they satirize it with a great deal of flair, and in a way that turns out to have a surprisingly hefty inner logic.

This is how you do a sequel. Serious Sam 2 preserves the frantic, enemies-everywhere, off-the-rails action that makes the series what it is, while adding new things. Admittedly, the story is crap and just serves to shuffle you from one area to the next, but the game itself is solid. The levels have a real sense of scale to them, and the game manages to throw â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ at you from all angles without you ever feeling overwhelmed; you're in control just enough to keep from losing it entirely.

The enemies you fight range from your old classics like suicide bombers and those horse-skeleton things, but you've also got entirely new enemies such as rocket-launching dinosaurs, sawblade ninjas, and spiky purple balls. There's a nice mix of old and new, and the enemies are unique enough to make you change up your tactics. Near the end of the story campaign the action wears a little thin as the game runs out of cool things to let you shoot, but the ride as a whole is solid. The addition of mounted turrets and vehicles complements the massive level sizes and makes for some fun setpieces as well. The visuals are clearly aged, but the widescreen support is good and you can tell what you're looking at.

In all, Serious Sam 2 is a brilliant step up for the series, preserving the core gameplay while keeping things fun and inventive. It's a balanced mix of old and new that is sure to delight fans and newcomers alike.

Do you want to see what a game franchise looks like when it is going through a mid-life crisis? Serious Sam 2 is that mid-life crisis, bending backwards to try and please both gamers on the old-fangled Xbox and PC by Fischer-Pricing the entire game, putting on wacky, kooky airs (in the midst of you ending thousands of lives with high-caliber weaponry), and by â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing up what made Serious Sam so awesome. But like a mid-life crisis, underneath the new earring, KISS face tattoo, and the new â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥-extension automobile, it's still Sam, except more â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing irritating. However, it's the Sam that gets swept under the rug when people look back on the franchise.

Taking a graphical departure and leaving behind almost all of the old enemies, Serious Sam 2 is a lengthy, challenging , and funny FPS.  With a huge array of weapons, vehicular combat, and secrets galore, you'll never find yourself short on ways to splatter your enemies.  The story never takes itself too seriously and is very cleverly written.  Graphics and music are excellent, and the game is very long for an FPS--almost too long.  There are many genuinely challenging areas, but only a few are truly frustrating.  If you like to decimate large waves of enemies and enjoy funny storytelling, this is a great title to have.

For the sake of the reader and myself, I write two versions of a review: a longer, more in-depth review on Pastebind (found here: http://pastebin.com/petwut4U ), and a shorter, summarized version here on Steam.

Gameplay: More of the Sam you come to love, albeit slightly watered down. Guns are more or less the same from SS1, the levels are just as huge and sprawling, but nowhere near the intensity of the waves of SS1. Bosses are pretty good overall. Losing all your weapons between worlds and some hitscan enemies aren't the greatest. Lives system doesn't really work that well. Otherwise, game is still a lot of fun, just not as good as Serious Sam 1. 8/10.

Story: Actual cutscenes this time around, usually a good laugh and generally worth watching. Never becomes anything close to dramatic, which is perfectly fine. 7/10.

Graphics: A timeless art style, very cartoonish, bright and colorful. New monster designs are great. The graphics options for this game are enough to make your head spin. Hippie blood is the greatest thing ever. 5/5.

Sound: OST not as good as SS1, but still pretty good overall. Very comedic voice acting. Sound design just as good as SS1. 4/5.
